docs.lead_paragraph: Over the past 30 years, the slow creep of multiple sclerosis has cost Bill Ferrer his business, his ability to walk, and ultimately his ability to live unaided. But it spared his self-deprecating humor and his boundless optimism.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; Man Who Gives Support Finds There Is Some for Him

docs.snippet: Over the past 30 years, the slow creep of multiple sclerosis has cost Bill Ferrer his business, his ability to walk, and ultimately his ability to live unaided.     But it spared his self-deprecating humor and his boundless optimism.

docs.lead_paragraph: BIDDING FOR OFFICE LANDLORD -- The feverish competition over Equity Office Properties Trust, the nation's largest office landlord, appeared to be nearing an end, with shareholders to vote on the best offer today. [C1.] JOBS URGES UNFETTERED MUSIC -- Steven P. Jobs, Apple's chief executive, jolted the record industry by calling on its largest companies to allow online music sales unfettered by antipiracy software. [C1.] WAL-MART and UNION AGREE -- In an extraordinary meeting in Washington, the chiefs of Wal-Mart Stores and the Service Employees International Union will stand together today and agree on a series of goals for achieving universal health coverage, according to people briefed on the matter. [C2.] PROSECUTORS DEMAND RECORDS -- Federal prosecutors have subpoenaed records of Allied Capital, a business development company, in an effort to discover how private investigators it hired may have obtained the phone records of one of its leading critics.[C1.] G.E. MAPS ITS FUTURE -- Jeffrey R. Immelt, chairman of General Electric, has designated some fields as promising areas for the company, and jettisoned some others seen as slow-growers. Among the winners: clinical diagnosis, security, energy services and ''green'' products. [C1.] HOLLYWOOD IN WASHINGTON -- The Motion Picture Association of America came to Washington to press its agenda of fighting piracy, obtaining new tax advantages and reining in runaway movie and television production. Armed with some A-list talent, like the actor Will Smith, above, the group said that film and TV production accounts for $30 billion in wages.[C3.] SAMSUNG TO PAY $90 MILLION -- Samsung Electronics of South Korea agreed to pay $90 million to settle civil charges that it conspired with six other makers of computer chips to fix prices, the attorneys general of 41 states announced. [C8.] TAURUS BACK ON THE ROAD -- The Ford Taurus, the onetime best-selling car line that was retired last year because of dwindling sales, is coming back to life as the new nameplate on the slow-selling Ford Five Hundred sedan. [C4.] TOYOTA'S PROFIT POINTS THE WAY -- Another quarter of record profits and sales by Toyota Motor painted a picture of a company whose momentum is pushing it relentlessly closer to becoming the No. 1 global auto company, analysts said. [C4.] THE BIGGER-IS-BETTER APPROACH -- Toyota is promoting its new full-size Tundra pickup by projecting an image of itself that Americans have not seen before from the automaker -- one built on horsepower and ''my brakes are bigger than yours'' machismo. Advertising. [C4.] HIGH DEMAND HELPS CISCO -- The Internet equipment maker Cisco Systems reported a 36 percent jump in profit in its second fiscal quarter, benefiting from growing demand for bigger, faster networks that can handle video. The news bolstered Wall Street confidence that the company, a highflier in the 1990s, was again enjoying steady growth. [C3.] BERNANKE'S SOLUTION TO WAGE GAP -- Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, said that bolstering education and training, rather than erecting trade barriers would help narrow the economic gap between low- and high-income workers [C13.] MORTGAGE INSURER BUYS RIVAL -- A mortgage insurance provider, the MGIC Investment Corporation, has agreed to buy a rival, the Radian Group, for $4.9 billion in stock to form a combined company with total assets of nearly $15 billion.[C4.] CHINA DEFERS ON EMISSION LIMITS -- China said that wealthier countries must take the lead in curbing greenhouse gas emissions and refused to say whether it would agree to any emissions limits that might hamper its booming economy. [A9.] LET'S GO (GERM-FREE) SHOPPING -- Arkansas is poised to become the first state in the nation to officially encourage grocery stores to offer sanitary wipes to customers who use shopping carts. [A11.] PUBLIC BROADCASTING, IN SPANISH -- Public broadcasting executives are expected to announce a new Spanish-language network that will go on the air on March 5 in American cities with large Latino populations. [E1.] EX-HEAD OF AIRLINE DIES -- M. Lamar Muse, the first president of Southwest Airlines, who took the job when the airline had no planes, tens of thousands of dollars of debt and about $100 in the bank, died Monday in Dallas. He was 86. [A16.]

docs.lead_paragraph: The Caucus Question of the Day: Would you be willing to pay higher taxes so that everyone could have health insurance?
docs.abstract: Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama have both called for universal health coverage, but John Edwards is the first out of the gate with an actual plan.
docs.snippet: Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama have both called for universal health coverage, but John Edwards is the first out of the gate with an actual plan.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush released his $2.9 trillion, 2,500-page budget on Monday and, well, it's not receiving good reviews from the Democrats. Granted, his budget usually doesn't win much praise from the opposition, but this is the first time the Democrats have the power to do anything about it (though they may have a tough time asserting their own priorities, The Times's Steven R. Weisman writes).

headline.main: Bush Stays True to Self in Budget

docs.abstract: President Bush released his $2.9 trillion, 2,500-page budget on Monday and, well, it's not receiving good reviews from the Democrats.

docs.lead_paragraph: The UnitedHealth Group cut its 2007 revenue forecast yesterday after determining that membership in its full-service Medicare plans for older patients would probably decline “modestly” this year.
